subject: RE: [junit] Proposed parameterized test syntax for JUnit 4
msgSnippet: Eugene, I don t organize my tests with one test class per model class. Instead, I have one test class per fixture. For example, if I wanted to test with both
messageBody:
Eugene,

I don't organize my tests with one test class per model class. Instead, I have one test class per fixture. For example, if I wanted to test with both empty lists and lists with elements, I would have two classes:

class EmptyListTest {
List<String> list;
@Before public void initialize() {
list= new ArrayList<String>();
}
...
}

class PopulatedListTest {
List<String> list;
@Before public void initialize() {
list= new ArrayList<String>();
list.add("one");
list.add("two");
}
...
}

Following this style, different test methods in a single parameterized test class will all share the same parameters.

The JUnit tests are not currently organized very well with respect to this principle. I find that when I am in a hurry to write the next test I tend to put it in the same test class as the last test. I need to 1) re-organize the JUnit tests and 2) slow down a little.

I always err on the side of running too many tests, so I don't find it hugely annoying to run all the tests related to a change even when I have multiple test classes per model class.

Sincerely yours,

Kent Beck
Three Rivers Institute

>
> David, Kent,
>
> I agree that one-class-instance-per-test is a good enforcement (as
> long as it does not cause performance issues). Usually it is also
> practical to have single test class per class under test, it is just
> easier to see what tests you have.
>
> Imagine that there is AThing class with N methods.
> Test class AThingTest would have K test methods that can be
> groupped
> by use cases for AThing class implementing scenarious for
> each possible
> execution flow (e.g. if all AThing methods are atomic and
> stateless you
> would have at least N test methods).
> Note that different use cases may have different input and
> initialization data for AThing class under test. E.g. methods
> X and Y of
> AThing class have different parameters and as a result
> methods testX and
> testY will require different parameters.
> In current implementation of @Parameters in JUnit4 the
> above scenario
> will require to implement two separate test classes and in my
> opinion it
> is a huge an annoying limitation because user will have to
> find and run
> all test classes that are testing AThing on AThing change.
>
> Thanks
>
> Eugene
>
>
> David Saff wrote:
>
> >Cedric,
> >
> >I think there's a lot of room for different ways of
> organizing tests.
> >For me, it's good for JUnit 4 to keep the
> one-class-instance-per-test
> >philosophy of JUnits 1 through 3. I find that if my code
> depends on too
> >much global state, or too many collaborators, I begin to feel it,
> >because it gets harder to test in JUnit. I find that if I
> ignore this
> >pain in the tests, eventually it becomes a pain in the code,
> so I like
> >JUnit's early warning.
> >
> >With that in mind, I find that having the parameters on the
> constructor
> >reminds me of what's really going on.
> >
> >David Saff
> >
> >Cédric Beust ♔ wrote:
> >
> >
> >
> >>Hi Kent,
> >>
> >>On 10/4/05, Kent Beck <kentb@...> wrote:
> >>
> >>
> >>>Cedric,
> >>>
> >>>If I need different sets of parameters for different
> tests, I put the
> >>>tests
> >>>in different classes. This way, tests don't see parameters
> they don't
> >>>need.
> >>>The same goes for fields set in a set-up method. Only
> tests that need
> >>>exactly the same setup go in the same class.
> >>>
> >>>
> >>Well, that's certainly the way it works in JUnit3, but I
> thought the whole
> >>point behind the parameterized proposal was to allow tests
> to receive
> >>parameters?
> >>
> >>A lot of TestNG users like this feature, so that instead of
> passing, say,
> >>the path of an XML file in the constructor and then
> referencing it in your
> >>test method:
> >>
> >>public VerifyXmlTest(String xmlPath) {
> >>this.xmlPath = xmlPath;
> >>}
> >>
> >>public void testXml() {
> >>// use this.xmlPath
> >>}
> >>
> >>You pass it directly to the test method:
> >>
> >>public void testXml(String xmlPath) {
> >>}
> >>
> >>Cleaner, and it also features better isolation since you
> are not exposing
> >>this parameter to test methods that don't need it.
> >>
> >>--
> >>Cédric
